Text column will wrap text if the progress doesn't fit comfortably, that may be what's happening.

If you post a screenshot and some code, maybe I can give you some suggestions how to achieve what you are looking for.

Sure, here's a picture of what it is + where I want it to be moved to:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42872277/83637076-001eda00-a575-11ea-9f2e-d1317ee45b4a.png)
And here's some of my code:
```py
table = Table(title="Settings")
    table.add_column("Setting", style="red", no_wrap=True)
    table.add_column("Value", style="blue", no_wrap=True)

    table.add_row("Host", host)
    table.add_row("Webserver port", str(port))
    table.add_row("RPC Port", str(rpcport))
    table.add_row("Update interval", str(interval))
    table.add_row("Running on", "Development server" if dev else "Production server")
    table.add_row("Logging level", "Debug" if debug else "Warning")

    console.print(Panel("Red Discord Bot Dashboard - Webserver", box=rich.box.HEAVY, expand=False), justify="center")
    console.print(Columns([table, progress.get_renderable()], equal=True))

    vartask = progress.add_task("Update variable", status="[bold blue]Starting...[/bold blue]")
    cmdtask = progress.add_task("Update commands", status="[bold blue]Starting...[/bold blue]")
```

After that, I pass the tasks to some threads, which call `progress.update` on them to change it to `Running...`.
As an additional note, I want it to be able to print tracebacks under it, in case it runs into an error, but it prints `logging.warning` right after the Progress, unless I do `console.print("\n\n")`, in which it can no longer edit the TextColumn.  I understand if that won't work though, due to limitations of the console.

The progress bar is designed to to go at the end of the terminal. If you want to include the progress information as part of some other content, then you would have to extend the Progress bar itself.

Try extending Progress and overriding `get_renderables` to yield your content. Something like this

```python
class MyProgress(Progress):
    def get_renderables(self):
        yield COLUMNS etc
```
Alright, thanks.  I'll take a look.

So, I played around a bit with the progress, and realized that `progress.make_tasks_table` is what I want.  However, the issue is that `progress.refresh` prints it out onto the console, but when it does that, it prints it under my settings table because the cursor does not start on the second column I have.  I tried making the tasks not visible at first, then making the table, then making them visible, but when it refreshed it, that made it print under the settings table again.  I tried starting as visible, and that worked a bit, but it printed the tasks before the table and such, which I don't want.  Either way though, when I call refresh on it again after changing it to "Running...", it would send it to underneath the table, since it's using `console.print` and the cursor is below the table.

I'm starting to realize that I don't think this is possible due to the limitation of the console, and has nothing to do with this library.  Thanks for your help though with everything.  Feel free to close this issue, unless I'm missing something.

If you use the `print` method on Progress, it should reposition the cursor so that it doesn't break the visions.

Run the following for a demo:

```
python -m rich.progress
```
